official-title.#text:
To establish a grant program to help State and local law enforcement agencies reduce the risk of
			 injury and death relating to the wandering characteristics of some
			 children with autism and other disabilities.

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is
			 amended by adding at the end the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Title I of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968/t:I

header.#text:
Grant program to reduce injury and death relating to the wandering and safety of individuals with
			 disabilities

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: may make grants to law enforcement agencies to—

text.#text: The

reduce the risk of injury and death relating to the wandering characteristics of some individuals
			 with autism and other disabilities; and
safeguard the well-being of individuals with disabilities during interactions with law enforcement.
A grant awarded under this section shall be—
distributed directly to a law enforcement agency; and
used to—

provide education and resources to law enforcement agencies, first responders, schools, clinicians,
			 and the public in order to—
reduce the risk of wandering by individuals with autism or other disabilities;
help to identify signs of abuse in individuals with autism or other disabilities;
increase personal safety and survival skills for individuals with autism or other disabilities; and

facilitate effective communication with individuals who have communication-related disabilities,
			 including the use of assistive communication techniques and technology;
provide training and emergency protocols for school administrators, staff, and families;
provide response tools and training for law enforcement and search-and-rescue agencies, including—
tracking technology;
reverse 911 technology;
assistive communication technology;
Endangered Missing Advisories; and
Federal search-and-rescue guidelines for special needs children; or

provide response tools and training to law enforcement agencies in order to recognize and respond
			 to individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities.

header.#text: Standards and best practices for use of tracking devices

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
and leading
			 research, advocacy, self-advocacy, and service organizations, shall
			 establish standards and best practices relating to the use of tracking
			 technology to monitor children with autism and other disabilities.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Secretary of Health and Human Services

text.#text: Not later than 120 days after the date of enactment of this part, the
shall determine—

the criteria used to determine which individuals would benefit from the use of a tracking device;
			 and
who should have direct access to the tracking system; and

determines are necessary to the
			 administration of a tracking system, including procedures in order to—

text.#text: may establish standards and best practices the
safeguard the privacy of the data used by the tracking device such that—
access to the data is restricted to agencies determined necessary by the
use of the data is solely for the purpose of preventing injury or death;

develop criteria to determine whether use of the tracking device is the least restrictive
			 alternative in order to prevent risk of injury or death prior to issuing
			 the tracking device, including the previous consideration of less
			 restrictive alternatives;

provide training for law enforcement agencies to recognize signs of abuse in their interactions
			 with applicants;
establish a complaint and investigation process to address—
incidents of noncompliance by grant recipients with the best practices established by the
use of a tracking device over the objection of a child with a disability; and

the role which State agencies responsible for providing services to children with developmental
			 disabilities and State agencies responsible for child protective services
			 should have in the administration of a tracking system.
In establishing the standards and best practices required under subparagraph (A), the
